title: How to Treat Acid Reflux in Newborns

steps.title: Recognize symptoms of acid reflux.
steps.content: Recognize symptoms of acid reflux. Watch your baby to see if they exhibit symptoms of acid reflux before making lifestyle changes. Typical signs and symptoms of acid reflux in newborns include: [2] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Spitting up Vomiting or regurgitation Not gaining weight or growing Being irritable during feedings Loss of appetite or refusing to eat Wheezing, coughing, or hoarseness Choking, gagging, or difficulty swallowing

steps.title: Change your baby formula or bottle feeding routine.
steps.content: Change your baby formula or bottle feeding routine. Talk to your pediatrician before changing the way you feed your baby with a bottle. Depending on the severity of your baby’s reflux, they may suggest the following changes: [3] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Feed your baby more often, but reduce the amount of formula or milk you give them to avoid reflux. Thicken the formula with oatmeal, carob bean thickener, or another type of thickener that your pediatrician recommends. Try a different brand of formula, or remove cow’s milk protein from your baby’s diet. [4] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you’re breastfeeding, remove all forms of dairy from your diet. [5] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Make sure your baby’s bottle nipple is the right size. This allows your baby to get the right amount of milk without swallowing air. If your baby is choking, coughing, has difficulty swallowing, or is refusing to eat, try a slower flowing nipple. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Modify breastfeeding techniques.
steps.content: Modify breastfeeding techniques. Babies who are breastfed may experience slightly less reflux because breast milk digests faster than formula. [7] X Research source Similar to bottle feeding, changing your breastfeeding routine may help treat your newborn’s reflux, but talk to a lactation consultant or a breastfeeding medicine specialist before making any changes. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Breastfeed for shorter amounts of time, but more frequently throughout the day to help reduce reflux. [9] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Eliminate different foods from your diet to see if this eases your newborn’s reflux. For example, you could avoid dairy, beef, or eggs to see if one might be the culprit. [10] X Research source Thicken breast milk with rice cereal or another thickener that your pediatrician recommends. [11] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Burp your baby more frequently.
steps.content: Burp your baby more frequently. If your baby seems irritated while feeding, stop the session, burp your baby, then begin feeding again. Your baby may reflux more often when burping with a full stomach, so increased burping may relieve pressure in their belly and prevent reflux. [12] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Use the following schedule as a guideline for burping: [13] X Research source Burp your baby every 2 to 3 ounces (60 to 90 mL) if you bottle feed, or each time you switch breasts if you breastfeed. Change your baby’s position if they don’t burp after a few minutes. Always burp your baby when feeding time is over.

steps.title: Hold your baby upright for 30 minutes after feeding.
steps.content: Hold your baby upright for 30 minutes after feeding. Keeping your baby in an upright position may relieve reflux or prevent acids from creeping up. Make sure to hold them upright for about 20 to 30 minutes after you feed them. [14] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Keep your baby upright over your shoulder or sitting on your knee. [15] X Research source Try not to bounce your baby around or provide too much stimulation after a feed. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Place your baby on their back to sleep.
steps.content: Place your baby on their back to sleep. Doctors recommend that babies sleep on their backs to minimize the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). [17] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source There is no evidence that placing a baby on their side or stomach helps with reflux. [18] X Research source However, there is evidence that babies placed on their side or stomach are at higher risk for sudden infant death syndrome. [19] X Research source Place your baby to sleep on a firm mattress, and make sure their crib has no blankets, bumpers, or stuffed animals that might suffocate them. [20] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Do not raise one end of the crib or elevate the mattress with a foam block, wedge, or pillow. Keep your baby on a firm, flat, and level sleep surface. [21] X Research source Even if your baby is regurgitating or vomiting, place them on their back. Babies automatically cough or swallow fluid that they spit up because of their gag reflex, and this naturally prevents choking. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Consider natural remedies.
steps.content: Consider natural remedies. There is a natural product called “gripe water” that some people believe eases gas, reflux, and other baby ailments. There is no scientific evidence that gripe water is effective in treating reflux, but consult with your baby’s doctor if you are interested in trying a natural remedy. [23] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Be aware that the World Health Organization (WHO) doesn’t recommend giving gripe water to babies under 6 months. [24] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Make sure to speak to your doctor before giving your baby gripe water. Many brands of gripe water include ingredients like fennel, peppermint, lemon balm, chamomile, ginger, and sodium bicarbonate. [25] X Research source If you want to trial gripe water with your baby, look at the ingredient list closely. Avoid formulations that contain sugars or alcohols. [26] X Research source

steps.title: Visit your pediatrician.
steps.content: Visit your pediatrician. If making lifestyle changes doesn’t ease your newborn’s reflux or their symptoms get worse, schedule an appointment with a pediatrician. [27] X Research source You should also see your baby’s pediatrician if they have any of the following symptoms: [28] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Crying more than usual or being extremely irritable Failing to gain weight or gaining less weight than expected for their age Problems swallowing or breathing Projectile vomiting Vomiting in large amounts Vomit that contains blood or looks like coffee grounds Vomiting with bile (making the vomit green or yellow in color) Vomiting or regurgitation that begins when they’re younger than 2 weeks or older than 6 months Rectal bleeding or stools that contain blood No wet diapers for 3 hours or more, or a lack of energy

steps.title: Get a diagnosis.
steps.content: Get a diagnosis. A pediatrician will examine your baby and ask you questions about their symptoms. If symptoms suggest that your baby may have a gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) complication or another type of health problem, your pediatrician may recommend further medical testing. [29] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Your doctor may order one of the following tests: [30] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Upper GI series Esophageal pH and impedance monitoring Upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy and biopsy

steps.title: Give your baby medication.
steps.content: Give your baby medication. Depending on the outcome of your doctor’s visit and possible testing, your doctor may suggest lifestyle changes and/or prescribe medication. [31] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Reflux medications usually lower the amount of acid the stomach makes, which may improve symptoms and heal the lining of the esophagus. However, infants taking these medicines may have a higher chance of experiencing certain types of infections. [32] X Trustworthy Source National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Health information from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, a division of the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Follow your doctor’s dosing instructions. Do not give your baby medication unless your doctor tells you to. [33] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Your doctor will likely prescribe proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) or H2 blockers to decrease acid production. [34] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Tighten the esophageal sphincter with surgery.
steps.content: Tighten the esophageal sphincter with surgery. In very rare cases, some babies may need surgery to tighten the muscle that blocks food from coming back up. [35] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source The procedure, called fundoplication, is generally only done on babies that have severe breathing problems with their reflux. [36] X Research source
